item.description:
Biography

I am currently a PhD candidate at the University of Illinois at Chicago where I am creating a platform, called IDBac, to make finding new medicines from bacteria a little less serendipitous. This has led to an unbelievable and exciting education in Natural Product Discovery, Mass Spectromety, and Microbial Biosynthesis. I have been fortunate to become certified in Dry-Suit SCUBA and had the opportunity to collect samples in such places as the remote fjords of Iceland. My R posts and great content from the broader R community can be found at R-Bloggers.

item.title: The Subtleties of Shiny Reactive Programming: Lapply and For Loops
item.description:
Why Read This?

  1. You want to understand why for loops can fail to produce desired results in an R Shiny app.
  2. You want an example of creating a dynamic number of plots within an R Shiny app.

A Minimal, Reproducible Example

First, let’s look at the minimal reprex. This is an R Shiny app that uses modules to display a dynamic number of plots.

  • plot_overlay_ui() is a Shiny module ui function that returns a <tag> list containing our plot(s).

  • plot_overlay_server() is a Shiny module server function that creates the plot.

  • ui() is a regular Shiny ui function that contains the code to create the main skeleton of the user interface.

  • server() is a regular Shiny server function that contains logic to run the app.

  • plot_data() is a reactive expression that returns a list, where each list element is a vector representing a column of mtcars selected using the checkboxGroupInput.

  • multi_plot_ui renders ui/html that is dynamically generated… this will hold our dynamically-generated plots

  • And callModule(plot_overlay_server,...) is where the focus of this blog takes place.

library(shiny)

plot_overlay_ui <- function(id) {
  ns <- NS(id)
  tagList(
    plotOutput(ns("my_plot"), 
               width = "100%")
  )
}
# -------------------------------------------------------------------------

plot_overlay_server <- function(input,
                                output,
                                session, 
                                spec,
                                plot_name) {
  
  output$my_plot <- renderPlot({
    
    plot(spec, 
         main = plot_name)
    
  })
}
# -------------------------------------------------------------------------

ui <- fluidPage(
  titlePanel("Reprex"),
  sidebarLayout(
    sidebarPanel(
      checkboxGroupInput("selected_sample",
                         label = "Select Strain",
                         choices = seq_along(mtcars))
    ),
    mainPanel(
      uiOutput("multi_plot_ui")
    )
  )
)
# -------------------------------------------------------------------------

server <- function(input, output) {
  
  plot_data <- reactive({
    col_select <- as.integer(input$selected_sample)
    lapply(col_select, function(x) mtcars[,x])
  })
  
  observeEvent(input$selected_sample, {
    req(!is.null(input$selected_sample))
    req(plot_data())
    
    output$multi_plot_ui <- renderUI({
      
      lapply(seq_along(input$selected_sample),
             function(n) {
               return(plot_overlay_ui(paste0("n", n)))
             })
    })
    
    lapply(seq_along(input$selected_sample),
           function(i){
             callModule(plot_overlay_server,
                        paste0("n", i),
                        spec = plot_data()[[i]],
                        plot_name = i)
           }
    )
    
    # for (i in seq_along(input$selected_sample)) {
    #   callModule(plot_overlay_server,
    #              paste0("n", i),
    #              spec = plot_data()[[i]],
    #              plot_name = i)
    # }
    
  })
}

shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

Lapply vs For Loops in Shiny

My original code to generate the multiple server functions to generate plots was:

# the for loop
for (i in seq_along(input$selected_sample)) {
  callModule(plot_overlay_server,
             paste0("n", i),
             spec = plot_data()[[i]],
             plot_name = i)
}

While this was able to produce multiple plots, all of the plots were identical and represented the plot created during the last iteration of the loop. I was convinced the problem was a regression in my Shiny abilities and that I was simply missing an session$ns() or the like.

After convincing myself everything was correct, I tried an experiment that I thought was crazy enough to work because of the underlying mechanics… change the for-loop to a lapply.

# the lapply
lapply(seq_along(input$selected_sample),
       function(i){
         callModule(plot_overlay_server,
                    paste0("n", i),
                    spec = plot_data()[[i]],
                    plot_name = i)
       }
)

And the lapply worked! Multiple plots representing the correct, selected data were displayed!

My best guess was that for a lapply() every iteration was run in its own environment. This turns out to be exactly what allows this to work, and I am honestly surprised I hadn’t encountered this before.

Learn More!

If you would like to learn more, Barbara Borges Ribeiro (https://github.com/bborgesr) has a wonderful Gist explaining what is going on with for loops vs lapply in Shiny: https://gist.github.com/bborgesr/e1ce7305f914f9ca762c69509dda632e

item.title: Minimizing Taxonomic and Natural Product Redundancy in Microbial Libraries Using MALDI-TOF MS and the Bioinformatics Pipeline IDBac
Unit test renderUI inside Shiny modules
item.description:
I have run across this a few times and hope this might help someone. As Shiny apps get more complicated and you start to use Shiny modules you will likely run across use cases for using renderUI within modules. Sometimes it is desirable to be able to test these using packages like testthat.

However, you will run into a problem because of a missing session$ns.

library(testthat)
library(shiny)

Example adapted from: https://shiny.rstudio.com/articles/modules.html

badExample <- function(session){
  selectInput(session$ns("col"), 
              "Columns",
              names(data),
              multiple = TRUE)
}


columnChooserUI <- function(id) {
  ns <- NS(id)
  uiOutput(ns("controls"))
}

columnChooser <- function(input, output, session, data) {
  output$controls <- renderUI({
    badExample(session)
    
  })

  return(reactive({
    validate(need(input$col, FALSE))
    data[,input$col]
  }))
}

So, that’s not a great example of why you would need a function, but it’ll work for this demo.

So, what do we pass for session?

print(
badExample(session = "IdontKnow")
)
## Error in session$ns: $ operator is invalid for atomic vectors

What we can do is recreate the namespace function for testing purposes.

session <- NULL
session$ns <- function(id) {id}

Now we should get back the html and setup whatever tests we like (for long html testthat::expect_known_hash() is helpful). (Note: print included just for rendering this post.)

print(
badExample(session)
)
## <div class="form-group shiny-input-container">
##   <label class="control-label" for="col">Columns</label>
##   <div>
##     <select id="col" multiple="multiple"></select>
##     <script type="application/json" data-for="col">{}</script>
##   </div>
## </div>

Note: the object returned is not character.

class(badExample(session))
## [1] "shiny.tag"

item.title: Genome Sequence of Marine-Derived Streptomyces sp. Strain F001, a Producer of Akashin A and Diazaquinomycins
Using the Open-Source MALDI TOF-MS IDBac Pipeline for Analysis of Microbial Protein and Specialized Metabolite Data
Structuring Shiny App Development
item.description:
Part One: Scope

This is going to be a fairly opinionated post about my not novel but recent revelations as to how I think Shiny apps should be formatted. By formatting I don’t mean UI formatting, code style, etc. I mean how one might organize, holistically, a Shiny app to help maximize readability, stability, and scalability. Again not novel, just me getting my thoughts “on paper’.

Before now my server() sections kind of looked like this:

I am aware that it is possible to “modularize” a shiny app and there is good info on that from RStudio here and Steph Locke here.

I am not a fan of this approach for a couple of reasons:

  • I think it can add unnecessary complexity to small applications
  • I think it’s difficult to use with large applications that have highly interconnected reactivity
  • But, in reality, it’s likely I just haven’t spent enough time trying it ¯\(ツ)/¯

Part Two: Straight to the Point

I think abstracting Shiny apps to small functional components is most helpful when done at the most fundamental level. Luckily there are two elements of the R ecosystem that are crazy-complementary to Shiny apps:

  • Packages
  • Functions

Those links point to Hadley Wickham’s book R packages and a chapter of Advanced R, respectively.

And if we look at the first sentence of each:

R packages:
“In R, the fundamental unit of shareable code is the package.”

Advanced R:
“Functions are a fundamental building block of R…”

i.e. The tools you need to organize your app exist:

  • Start by making it a package
  • Then break your computation into standalone functions that reside outside the app

Part Three: A Shiny App is a Package

Making your Shiny app a package allows you to:

  • Easily distribute the app
  • Manage package dependencies
  • Write unit tests for your app (more on that in Part Five)
  • Easily include any needed data within the app (eg example data, models)
  • Organize your code

Creating an app as a package provides you a framework for development:

Dean Attali briefly described the basics of including a Shiny app within a package here. That formed the basis for how I now write Shiny apps, along with what I’ve learned from creating Shiny apps as Windows executables using Jonathan Hill’s “RInno” package

Part Four: Shiny Apps Consist of Functions

Concept One: Reactive Expressions are Basically Functions

In reality it’s more complicated but a lot of the basic components of a Shiny app (e.g. server(), reactive(), observe(), etc.) can be thought of as functions.

Imagine we have a simple app that has a slider input that represnents the number of pumpkins you sell per year, but you want the log10 of that number.

You could make a little reactive expression that would do this:

pumpkinLog <- reactive({
                log10(input$pumpkins)
              })

Now imagine we moved the slider input to 10 pumpkins. We then save pumpkinLog() to savedValue in the parent environment and close the app.

observe(
 savedValue <<- pumpkinLog()
)

What will printing savedValue give us?

print(savedValue)
   
  [1] 1

It gave us 1, the value we would expect to be returned from log10(10).

This is because, in essence, you are asking for the result of calling a reactive “function”.

And, just like in base R, functions can take as arguments the result given by calling another function.

Concept Two: Shiny Inputs Just Return a Value

This concept is pretty simple, input$... just stores the value of inputs. That’s phenomenally important because it means we can use input$... as an argument for another function.

If you don’t believe me check out below where I saved the inputs from an intermediate point within an app. And upon closing the app printed the values.

myInputs <<- as.list(input)
# close app

print(myInputs)

        $`rawORreanalyze`
        [1] "2"
        
        $idbacDirectoryButton
        [1] 1
        attr(,"class")
        [1] "integer"                "shinyActionButtonValue"
        
        $upperMass
        [1] 15000
        
        $updateIDBac
        [1] 0
        attr(,"class")
        [1] "integer"                "shinyActionButtonValue"
        
        $lowerMass
        [1] 3000

Part Five: Putting it All Together

So now we know we can use the value from calling a reactive(...) expression and the value returned by an input$... as inputs to functions.

That means we can do this:

# Saved as a seperate .r file, within R folder of package directory
# eg "pumpkinLogarithm.r"" would contain this:

pumpkinLogarithm <- function(pumpkins){
   log10(pumpkins)
}     

# Saved as a seperate .r file, within R folder of package directory
# eg "otherProduce.r""  would contain this:

totalProduce <- function(tomatoes, apples, loggedPumpkin){
  log10(tomatoes) + log10(apples) + loggedPumpkin
}

# Within your app's server function

pumpkinLog <- reactive({
                pumpkinLogarithm(pumpkins = input$numberOfPumpkins)
              })

groceries <- reactive({
               totalProduce(tomatoes = input$tomatoes,
                            apples   = input$apples,
                            pumpkins = pumpkinLog()
                            )
             })

So now you have two functions that live outside the Shiny app. Your server file is more succinct, especially in regard to the variables within each reactive or observe chunk that may have had reactive side effects.

Most importantly:

  • Because you are writing package functions you can wield the freaking awesome power of testthat!

I realize that this only tests the internals/non-reactiveness of an app, but there are other packages to test layout/reactivity, etc. But these can be hard to keep up with large apps that don’t have a stable codebase. For that you can reference the packages below

Examples:

  • https://github.com/rstudio/shinytest
  • http://rpubs.com/johndharrison/13408

I will expand this post if there’s interest but here’s an example of an app with a layout that takes at least partial example of all this:

  • https://github.com/chasemc/mzEasy

item.title: Coupling MALDI-TOF Mass Spectrometry Protein and Specialized Metabolite Analyses to Rapidly Discriminate Bacterial Function
First Experience With Scientific Publishing and Preprints
item.description:
My first scientific publication was published this month in PNAS: https://doi.org/10.1073/pnas.1801247115 and has been a long time coming. I began this project as an interim between my first and second rotations as a first-year PhD student, I am now in the second-half of my third year.

The manuscript took some time to prepare and apart from the usual: waiting for instrument time, repairs (LCQ used for initial derepilcation of desferrioxamines), etc., it was doubly-lengthy for two reasons:

Delay 1: Software development isn’t linear…especially when you have no development experience

In fact, we had orignally anticipated utilizing Bruker’s BioTyper software for the entire project. Had we stayed with using BioTyper, IDBac would have been prohibitively exclusive to only those well-funded labs who could afford software that is price-targeted for hospital-conglomerates. I had some very limited experience using KNIME, a “scientific workflow system”, in my previous job- doing excel-sheet mining of quality control data and some cheminformatics with FT-IR and HPLC method validation. Never having been exposed to “coding/scripting” I found KNIME intuitive, especially for smaller workflows. So I decided to do a quick layout of a potential analysis script in KNIME.

I hid the large network of functions, transformations, etc. within a handful of “metanodes” so that users press “play” it would create a directory to drag-and-drop files into, press “play” again and generate visualizations (dendrograms and 3-D principle components plots). While few in steps, it became obvious that it was less intuitive than I had believed and there was much that could be improved.

So I decided to learn R and began spending days, nights, weekends writing code, googling/reading/learning, and re-writing code. This morphed over the months into its current form of >2,000 lines of code that is accesible through a double-click to start executable and all analyses performed within a self-contained GUI. Briefly, IDBac is built to convert raw spectra to .mzXML, do spectra processing, perform hierarchical clustering (with factor-mapping), PCA, and network analysis. The next release is nigh and will also allow PCoA and t-SNE analyses and expand the input source types to .csv/.txt and natively-named Bruker-data.

Delay 2: Bench Science!

Like most things in life science we wound up doing a lot of confirmatory experiments that weren’t anticipated at the beginning of the project. An example of this was dereplicating desferrioxamines from the Micromonospora strains. I had noticed a common set of peaks in a number of strains by observing MS1 MALDI spectra (before the KNIME and R programs were written). When we were trying to decide strains for the paper I remembered this earlier observation and further searching in compound databases revealed a shortlist of compounds.
Luckily… in my second rotation with Dr. Alessandra Eustaquio I had helped with the genome sequencing of one of these strains (B006). Antismash predicted a siderophore and a few other compounds but the details were pretty buried. I had recently attended a genome annotation/comparative genomics workshop at Argonne National Laboratory using this and another strain. I went back to that data and found an intact biosynthetic gene cluster related to a compound on the short-list… desferrioxamine.

This still didn’t prove that the MS1 peaks correlated to these genes though, so we moved to gain chemical evidence for their presence. This consisted of a Bligh and Dyer extraction followed by high-res, accurate-mass Orbitrap MS2. This data supported the dereplication with intact MS accurate mass, MS/MS fragmentation, and iron-isotope analysis.

So… Preprints

In October of 2017 we finally had our experiments done, main manuscript written, supplementary materials finished, and software ready to test on a broader scale. But we knew the publishing step could take many months so we made the decision to submit a preprint to bioRxiv. This was also because we had been talking about the pipeline at conferences for some months… people seemed excited, but hadn’t really exposed experimental details. Also, a couple of labs at UIC and across the US had started using the software.

In the five months between first-preprint and when we were officially published, the preprint abstract was read over 1,200 times and the pdf of the article downloaded over 650 times. This means that we reached a large audience that was obviously interested in reading the research earlier than peer-review and prompted conversations with interested parties months earlier than it otherwise would have.

I keep seeing “Keep a lookout for our article that was just submitted to XX!”. I think our collective response should be: “Can you send me the link to the preprint?”

Take Home Message

Submit preprints.

Scientific progress is already slow, let’s do what we can to make it faster.

item.title: Tidy Tuesday 4-17-2018
item.description:
See here for more about tidy tuesday: https://github.com/rfordatascience/tidytuesday

library(tidyverse)
library(plotly)
library(ggrepel)

Read in data, remove punctuation from column names

inputData <- readxl::read_xlsx("data/4-19-18/global_mortality.xlsx")

names(inputData) <- str_trim(
        str_remove_all(names(inputData), "[[:punct:]]")
        )

Mean of each category grouped by country isn’t great, but for a tidy-tuesday it’ll do…

a2 <- inputData %>% group_by(country) %>%  summarize_if(is.numeric,mean)
a <- a2 %>% select(4:34) %>% replace(is.na(.), 0)
principleComponents <- prcomp(a) %>%
                          .$x %>%
                          as_tibble %>%
                          bind_cols(name=a2$country, .)
ggplot(principleComponents) +
    geom_label(aes(x=PC1,y=PC2,label=name)) +
    ggtitle("First and Second Principle Components")

principleComponents2 <- prcomp(a) %>%
                          .$rotation %>%
                          as_tibble %>%
                          bind_cols(name=colnames(a), .)

HIV in Africa and and Cancer in First-World Countries are separable by the first Principle Component

ggplot(principleComponents2) +
    geom_label(aes(x=PC1,y=PC2,label=name)) +
      ggtitle("First and Second Principle Components, Variable Contributions")

Let’s look at one more set

ggplot(principleComponents) +
    geom_label(aes(x=PC3,y=PC4,label=name)) +
    ggtitle("Third and Fourth Principle Components")

Diabetes vs Malaria are disparate when comparing some Pacific Island nations and some African nations

ggplot(principleComponents2) +
    geom_label(aes(x=PC3,y=PC4,label=name)) +
    ggtitle("Third and Fourth Principle Components Variable Contributions")

The same data as presented above but as geom_bar such as in Julia Silge’s PCA tutorial here.

principleComponents2$name <- factor(principleComponents2$name, levels = principleComponents2$name[order(principleComponents2$PC1)])

w <- ggplot(principleComponents2) +
      geom_bar(stat="identity",aes(x=name,y=PC1,fill=name)) +
      theme(legend.position="none") +
      theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, hjust = 1,vjust=.4)) +
      theme(axis.title.x=element_blank()) +
      ggtitle("Factor Contributions to Principle Components")

ggplotly(w)
principleComponents$name <- factor(principleComponents$name, levels = principleComponents$name[order(principleComponents$PC1)])

w <- ggplot(principleComponents) +
        geom_bar(stat="identity",aes(x=name,y=PC1,fill=name)) +
        theme(legend.position="none") +
        theme(axis.text.x = element_blank()) +
        xlab("Hover Over Data for Country Names") +   
        ggtitle("Countries Separated in the First Principle Components Dimension")


ggplotly(w)

item.title: Animated t-SNE
item.description:
Load libraries

library(Rtsne)
library(createdatasets)
library(tweenr)
library(gganimate)
library(ggplot2)

set.seed(42)

Create data for t-SNE

# Get MNIST data for t-SNE
df_mnist    <- createMNIST()
df_sampled  <- df_mnist[sample(1:nrow(df_mnist), 1000), ]
mat_mnist   <- as.matrix(df_sampled[ , !(colnames(df_sampled) == "Class")])
whichNumber <- as.character(df_sampled[ , (colnames(df_sampled) == "Class")])

# Going to do parallel t-SNE later (and data has to be created for each instance on Windows R parallel,  so lets save the data as rds
saveRDS(mat_mnist, "data/mat_mnist.rds")
saveRDS(df_sampled, "data/df_sampled.rds")
saveRDS(whichNumber, "data/whichNumber.rds")

Run Parallel t-SNE

# Setup parallel
numCores <- parallel::detectCores()
numCores <- parallel::makeCluster(numCores - 1)

# Run parallel t-SNE        
e <- parallel::parLapply(numCores, 1:30 , function(x){
          set.seed(42)
          # Read in data tyo each instance
          df_sampled <- readRDS("data/df_sampled.rds")          
          mat_mnist <- readRDS("data/mat_mnist.rds")
          whichNumber <- readRDS("data/whichNumber.rds")

          c <- Rtsne::Rtsne(df_sampled, pca=TRUE, dims=2, perplexity = x, theta = 0.5, max_iter = 1000)
          d <- as.data.frame(c$Y)
          d <- cbind.data.frame(whichNumber, d, rep(x, times = nrow(d)))
          colnames(d) <- c("Number", "Dim.1", "Dim.2", "Framer")
          d
  
})
            parallel::stopCluster(numCores)

Create animation states and plots

tf <- tween_states(e, tweenlength = 2, statelength = 1, 
                   ease = c('cubic-in-out'), 
                   nframes = 500)


p <- ggplot(tf, aes(`Dim.1`, `Dim.2`, frame = Framer)) +
           geom_point(aes(colour = Number)) +
           ggtitle("t-SNE: Perplexity Step 1 to 30 by 1")

Create animation (GIF)

animation::ani.options(convert = "C:\\ImageMagick-7.0.7-Q16\\convert.exe")
animation::ani.options(interval = 1/15)

gganimate(p, title_frame = FALSE)

Information about the computer code was run on:

parallel::detectCores()
## [1] 8
a <- system('systeminfo', intern = TRUE)
a[3:4]
## [1] "OS Name:                   Microsoft Windows 10 Education"
## [2] "OS Version:                10.0.17763 N/A Build 17763"
a[16:17]
## [1] "Processor(s):              1 Processor(s) Installed."                                      
## [2] "                           [01]: AMD64 Family 21 Model 1 Stepping 2 AuthenticAMD ~3600 Mhz"
a[25]
## [1] "Total Physical Memory:     16,342 MB"

item.title: Tidy Tuesday 4-9-18
item.description:
library(tidyverse)
library(magrittr)

Read data into R

rawData <- readxl::read_excel("../../static/data/tidy_tuesday_week2.xlsx")
rawData
## # A tibble: 800 x 11
##     year Cornerback `Defensive Line~ Linebacker `Offensive Line~
##    <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>      <dbl>            <dbl>
##  1  2011   11265916         17818000   16420000         15960000
##  2  2011   11000000         16200000   15623000         12800000
##  3  2011   10000000         12476000   11825000         11767500
##  4  2011   10000000         11904706   10083333         10358200
##  5  2011   10000000         11762782   10020000         10000000
##  6  2011    9244117         11340000    8150000          9859166
##  7  2011    8000000         10000000    7812500          9500000
##  8  2011    7900000          9482500    7700000          9420000
##  9  2011    7400000          8450000    7200000          8880000
## 10  2011    7000000          8383266    7100000          8686750
## # ... with 790 more rows, and 6 more variables: Quarterback <dbl>,
## #   `Running Back` <dbl>, Safety <dbl>, `Special Teamer` <dbl>, `Tight
## #   End` <dbl>, `Wide Receiver` <dbl>

Check for missing values

rawData %>% 
  select_if(~any(is.na(.))) %>% 
  summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.)))
## # A tibble: 1 x 2
##   Quarterback `Special Teamer`
##         <int>            <int>
## 1          55                1

How many missing per year per field position?

rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.)))
## # A tibble: 8 x 11
##    year Cornerback `Defensive Line~ Linebacker `Offensive Line~ Quarterback
##   <dbl>      <int>            <int>      <int>            <int>       <int>
## 1  2011          0                0          0                0           3
## 2  2012          0                0          0                0          12
## 3  2013          0                0          0                0           7
## 4  2014          0                0          0                0          11
## 5  2015          0                0          0                0           3
## 6  2016          0                0          0                0           5
## 7  2017          0                0          0                0           3
## 8  2018          0                0          0                0          11
## # ... with 5 more variables: `Running Back` <int>, Safety <int>, `Special
## #   Teamer` <int>, `Tight End` <int>, `Wide Receiver` <int>

So…Quartback data is missing values compared to others, but max # missing values for any year across all positions is…

rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~sum(is.na(.))) %>% .[, 2:11] %>% max
## [1] 12

Find Max and Min values per year per field position

maxData <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~max(.[!is.na(.)]))
minData <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~min(.[!is.na(.)]))
b <- rawData %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
b %<>% drop_na(Salary)

Let’s take look at the distribution of the data

ggplot(b) +
    facet_wrap(~year)+
    geom_violin(aes(y = Salary, x = `Field Position`))+
    theme(axis.text.x=element_blank()) +
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary")

ggplot(b) + 
    facet_wrap(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_boxplot(aes(y = Salary, x = as.factor(year)))+
    theme(axis.text.x=element_blank()) +
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary")

c <- maxData %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
c %<>% drop_na(Salary)
d <- minData %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
d %<>% drop_na(Salary)

colnames(b) <- c("Year", "Field Position", "Salary")
colnames(c) <- c("Year", "Field Position", "Salary")
colnames(d) <- c("Year", "Field Position", "Salary")
ggplot(c) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_line(data=c, aes(x=`Year`, y=`Salary`, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha = .55)+
    geom_line(data=d, aes(x=`Year`, y=`Salary`, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha = .55)+
    geom_jitter(data=b, aes(x=`Year`, y=`Salary`, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha = .15)+
    scale_colour_discrete(guide = FALSE) +
    scale_y_continuous(labels=function(n){format(n, scientific = FALSE)})+
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))+
    labs(title= "Summary Plot os Salaries: \n Max (Lines), Min (Lines), All Values (Points)")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))   

kermit <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~moments::skewness(.[!is.na(.)]))

kermit<- kermit %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)


kermit %<>% drop_na(Salary)


ggplot(kermit) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_point(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`))+
    geom_line(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha=.5)+  
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))+
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary Skew")+
    labs(title= "Stalled Salaries Aren't the Only Issue for Running Backs, \n Skewed Salaries Persist as Well")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))     

kermit <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~moments::kurtosis(.[!is.na(.)]))

kermit<- kermit %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)


kermit %<>% drop_na(Salary)


ggplot(kermit) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_point(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`))+
    geom_line(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha=.5)+
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))+
    xlab("Years") +
    ylab("Salary Kurtosis")+
    labs(title= "Stalled Salaries Aren't the Only Issue for Running Backs, \n Skewed Salaries Persist as Well")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))

st <- rawData %>% group_by(year) %>% summarise_all(~sd(.[!is.na(.)]))
st <- st %>% tidyr::gather(`Field Position`, Salary, -year)
st %<>% drop_na(Salary)

ggplot(st) + 
    facet_grid(~`Field Position`)+
    geom_point(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`))+
    geom_line(aes(x=year, y=Salary, colour=`Field Position`), lwd=1.5, alpha=.5)+
    labs(title="Increasing Salary Standard Deviations Over Time")+
    theme(plot.title=element_text(hjust=0.5))+
    theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90, vjust = .5))

sessionInfo()

item.title: Beyond Rstats -> Rgames
item.description:
While R is traditionally an academically-oriented language (usually statistics) it has moved into some kind of grey-zone due to inclusive philosophies and an abundance of new packages.

Thinking about this recently, I wondered if anyone had written any interactive games in R- and the answer is “kind-of”. About 2 years ago, Shiny afficionado Dean Attali wrote an interactive game, which is interactive but still lacked dynamic movement of a piece/character, charactestic of many games.

After another brief search I came across Peter Prevos’ post in r-bloggers about pong in R. I thought that was it, my search was done! But a closer look at the title revealed that while he had “simulated” the game, he had yet to accomplish interactivity.

So here’s my proof of concept, super-glitchy, 10-min of coding attempt of a truly interactive game of Pong in R, using Shiny, dplyr, and ggvis. I had extended this to a game similar to Google dino-game easter egg (eg here)…but that seems to be on my other computer, or maybe I just dreamt that… so maybe another day, another post. :)

Feel free to modify this code into an actual full-fledged game if you are so inclined. Peters’ post even gives some ideas of incorporating sound and how to handle when the paddle misses/adding levels/and a “Game Over” screen.

Yeah, there’s currently no winner, the ball moves slowly, it might be a bit jumpy, I probably used the wrong syntax… let’s see your best, make it better… game on!

An online version can be found here: chasemc.shinyapps.io/PONG

# Code is very loosely based on https://www.r-bloggers.com/r-cade-games-simulating-the-legendary-game-of-pong/

library(shiny)
library(ggvis)
library(dplyr)

# Playing field boundary lines
boundaries <- tibble(x = c(0, 50, 50, 0), y = c(0, 0, 50, 50))
paddleHeight <- tibble(x = c(0, 0), y = c(10, 20))

# Playing field boundaries (depend on cex)
xmin <- 0
xmax <- 50
ymin <- 0
ymax <- 50

# Initial position
initialBallPosition <<- tibble(x=40,y=40)

# Paddle control
psize <- 4
ypaddle <- 4
paddleSpeed <- 3

# Set direction
dx <- runif(1, .5, 1)
dy <- runif(1, .5, 1) 

ui <- 
  fluidPage(
    column(width=3),
    column(width=6,
           h1("PONG in R: A Proof of Concept"),
           
           actionButton("reset","Reset"),
           ggvisOutput("p"),
           # The following code was modified based on https://stackoverflow.com/questions/24973549/r-shiny-key-input-binding
           tags$style(type="text/css", ".recalculating {opacity: 1.0;}"),
           tags$script('$(document).on("keydown", function (e) {
                       Shiny.onInputChange("mydata", [e.which, Math.random()]  );
                       });')  
    ),column(width=3)
    )

server <- function(input,output,session) {
  
  observeEvent(input$reset,{
  initialBallPosition <<- tibble(x=40,y=40)
  })
  
  # Update paddle position based on keyboard input  
  # Key map  
  # left  = 37
  # right = 39
  # up ter   = 38
  # down  = 40
  
  observeEvent(input$mydata,{
    if((is.null(input$mydata))){
      playerObjectInitial}else{
        if(input$mydata[1] == 37){
          # left arrow key is empty
        }else if(input$mydata[1] == 39){
          # right arrow key is empty
        }else if(input$mydata[1] == 38 && max(paddleHeight$y) < ymax - paddleSpeed){
          paddleHeight <<- paddleHeight %>% mutate(y=y+paddleSpeed)
        }else if(input$mydata[1] == 40 && min(paddleHeight$y) > ymin + paddleSpeed){
          paddleHeight <<-   paddleHeight %>% mutate(y=y-paddleSpeed)
        }
      }
  })
  
  paddleMove <- reactive({
    invalidateLater(100)
    paddleHeight
  })
  
  ballPosition <- reactive({
    
    invalidateLater(200)
    
    if (initialBallPosition$x > xmax ) {
      dx <<- -dx * runif(1, .9, 1.1) # Bounce 
      initialBallPosition <<- initialBallPosition %>% mutate(x = x + dx)
    }else if (initialBallPosition$y > ymax | initialBallPosition$y < ymin){
      dy <<- -dy * runif(1, .9, 1.1)
      initialBallPosition <<- initialBallPosition %>% mutate(y = y + dy)
    }else if((initialBallPosition$x < xmin+.1) && (initialBallPosition$y > min(paddleHeight$y) && initialBallPosition$y < max(paddleHeight$y)) ){
      dx <<- -dx * runif(1, .9, 1.1) # Bounce 
      initialBallPosition <<- initialBallPosition %>% mutate(x = x + dx)
    }else{
      initialBallPosition <- initialBallPosition %>% mutate(y = y + dy)
      initialBallPosition <- initialBallPosition %>% mutate(x = x + dx)
      initialBallPosition <<- initialBallPosition
    }
    
    initialBallPosition 
  })
  
  ggvis(x = ~x, y = ~y) %>% 
    
    layer_points(data=ballPosition,size:=100) %>% 
    layer_paths(data=boundaries) %>% 
    layer_paths(data=paddleMove, stroke := "red",strokeWidth := 5) %>% 
    scale_numeric( "x", domain = c(0,50)) %>% 
    scale_numeric( "y", domain = c(0,50)) %>%
    hide_axis(scale = "x") %>%
    hide_axis(scale = "y") %>% 
    bind_shiny("p")
  
}

# Run the application 
shinyApp(ui = ui, server = server)

item.title: A Shiny New World
item.description:
Disclaimer (and maybe dissapointment): This has no connection to Huxley’s dystopian.

Jump to Section:

  • Brief Introduction
  • Example Apps
  • Code and Presentation Slides
  • Resources for Beginners

Introduction

I recently gave a talk at a meetup in Chicago about an R Shiny app I am working on called IDBac. While there are plenty of example apps for Shiny I also wanted to create some examples of my own for now and any future instruction. Since the meetup had some scheduled time for attendees to work in groups or on their own I thought a nice demonstration of Shiny would be an app that could interactively create groups based on a self-reported skill level.

However I also wanted to include some introductory-type apps to cover a range of beginner to intermediate skill levels. So, in all, there are three suggested apps to look through, hopefully with each stepping up a degree in skill level needed for both data-wrangling and Shiny skills. Some links to tutorials and resources can be found at the end of the post.

  • App One
    • Was borrowed from RStudio’s example gallery and should be straightforward enough to learn some of the basics of Shiny as you go through tutorials.
      • Skills: simple data analysis, simple clustering, simple plotting with base R
  • App Two
    • Is based on the GapMinder dataset and includes two static ggplots and an interactive datatable.
      • Skills: simple data analysis, simple plotting with ggplot
  • App Three
    • Is the demonstration app on splitting Meetup attendees into groups. It uses googlesheets, jsonlite to parse API responses, and some more advanced data analysis (both purrr and lapply) and building a dynamic nested HTML table in Shiny.
      • Skills: Parsing API and JSON, googlesheets,dplyr, purrr (map), lapply, dynamic html tags in Shiny There are some challenges/suggestions included in each of the apps.

App One: Beginner Example

I find Joe Cheng’s k-means example to be pretty straightforward to point out the basic features of reactivity and chose this as challenge for beginner’s to get familiar with shiny. Trying to understand what happens when you “break” certain lines of the code and why inputs, outputs, and reactives are placed where they are.


App Two and Three: Beginner/Intermediate Examples


App Two: Plotting GapMinder Data

This example is pretty short and simple with an interactive dataframe and two static ggplots within three separate tabPanels.

There are some challenges/suggestions on the left side of the page. These include making the ggplots interactive.


App Three: Interactively Create Groups at a Meetup

Due to some technical difficulties with the display tech at the meetup I wasn’t able to present this app example since I was using a computer sans-R, but wanted to include it here.

Imagine:

You’re organizing an Rstats workshop through Meetup.com. You have a lot of participants and want to separate them into groups based on self-reported skill levels, how would you accomplish this with Shiny?

Of course there are many ways, but the simplest I thought of was to use Google Forms and connect responses to information retrieved from the Meetup.com API.

  1. First, you would need to setup a Google Form and send it to participants to fill out: Example Google Form here
    • The responses will be recorded into a Google Sheet.
      • For more information on using Google Sheets with R, please see Jenny Bryan and Joanna Zhao’s tutorial.
    • Copy the key for the Google Sheet (eg in bold below below)
      • https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/ 1xxtw88dEKDdQ1CoeLm46FWmNt3bqPSCGp4P7LA7BNv0
    • Find the code snippet below within the shiny app and replace “Insert Key Here” with your key
responses <- reactive({
      surveyResponses <- gs_key(" Insert Key Here ")
      surveyResponses %>%  gs_read(ws = "Form Responses 1")
      
  })
  1. Then create the json API GET request for your Meetup.com event. To do so you would go here, fill out the form, create the API, and copy the Signed URL that is created.
    • Find the code snippet below within the Shiny app and replace “Insert Signed URL Here” with your signed url.
listFromAPI<-read_json(" Insert Signed URL Here ")

Shiny Apps Code and Chicago R User Group Presentation Slides

All three examples, and my presentation, are available on github at: github.com/chasemc/Jan2018ShinyMeetupCRUG or by download as a package with:

# Install devtools if you haven't already
# install.packages(devtools)
devtools::install_github("chasemc/Jan2018ShinyMeetupCRUG")

All three apps are released under the MIT License.

Resources

  • Where to start:
    • swirlstats.com
    • r4ds.had.co.nz
    • Then move on to: adv-r.had.co.nz
  • Where to find answers to your questions:
    • stackexchange.com
    • community.rstudio.com
    • Web Search! (i.e. google.com)
      • E.g. (search: convert list to data frame in R)

And for those new to Shiny:

  • A few Shiny resources:
    • shiny.rstudio.com/tutorial
    • shiny.rstudio.com/articles
    • shiny.rstudio.com/gallery
    • shiny.rstudio.com/gallery/widget-gallery
    • deanattali.com/blog/building-shiny-apps-tutorial

item.title: IDBac: A Shiny App to Analyze Bacterial Fingerprints and Aid in the Discovery of Potential New Antibiotics
IDBac: A New Paradigm in Developing Microbial Libraries for Drug Discovery
Your Missing Step in Reproducible R Programming: Continuous Deployment
